intro: Bupleurum greuteri, commonly known as the Greuter's angelica, is a member of the Apiaceae family, characterized by its aromatic foliage and umbellate inflorescences. It is native to the mountainous regions of Central Asia, particularly in countries like Uzbekistan and Tajikistan. The plant typically grows to a height of 30–60 cm, featuring finely divided, fern-like leaves and small white to pale yellow flowers. Its roots are often harvested for their medicinal properties, used in traditional medicine for their purported anti-inflammatory and hepatoprotective effects. Bupleurum greuteri thrives in well-drained soils and is often found in rocky or alpine environments.
